bioghist.p: Edward Drinker Cope (1840-1897) was one of the leading paleontologists of the 19th century. He was a protege of Joseph Leidy, and avid collector of fossils. He is perhaps most famous for his intense competition with O.C. Marsh over the acquisition and intellectual credit for the discovery of dinosaur fossils.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains letters chiefly to William Wagner from Cope regarding the collection of fishes and fossils made in North Carolina and Tennessee and sent to the Wagner Free Institute of Science between April and November of 1869. The collection also includes a letter to Joseph Willcox from Cope concerning organization of the Institute, May 12, 1885, and a letter to Cope from F.S. Holmes concerning an offer to sell his collection of fossils, June 1869.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: An inventory is available in the repository.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Haverford College: Ms. Coll. 956 - Edward Drinker Cope Papers (although Haverford's collection does not include letters from Wagner or Willcox, the time periods of the two collections overlap).
